2. Long sentences should often, but not always, be broken up into short sentences. Considerable judgement and taste are required for deciding how and when this should be done. The student will find a suitable opportunity for practising this art of breaking up in 6 ξ 3 or 14 ξ 9.

The metaphorical language of Livy often requires ex- pansion or transformation, and the following examples of English expression may be studied as suggestive parallels to the Livy passages indicated, though nothing can take the place of extensive study of English authors. It is to be understood that these parallels by no means offer ready-made turnings of the Latin, but they may serve as the straw which may render the making of bricks easier for those who have not yet read enough of their own literature to gather easily for themselves They may furnish a hint as to how a translation may be framed, if the translator remembers that he must not be content with a loose paraphrase. ‘A brilliant gleam of success had lit up the fallen fortunes of Lauderdale' (10 ξ 2), ‘the Church was on the brink of destruction' (7 ξ 1), ‘ one parting beam of splendour broke through the clouded skies' (10 ξ 2),
